tutorial.title: Red-Black Tree Interactive Course
tutorial.welcome: Learn Red-Black Trees from scratch! This course will guide you step by step through all concepts and operations.

basics.title: What is a Red-Black Tree?
basics.desc:
Welcome! Let's start with the basics.

**A Red-Black Tree** is a special type of "Binary Search Tree" (BST) that **automatically stays balanced**.

ðŸ’¡ **What is a Binary Search Tree?**
Each node has at most two children. Left child values are smaller, right child values are larger.

ðŸ’¡ **Why do we need balance?**
If a tree grows lopsided (like a straight line), searching becomes slow. A balanced tree guarantees fast searches!

**The Five Red-Black Tree Properties:**
1. Every node is **red** or **black**
2. The **root** is always **black**
3. Every **NULL leaf** (empty child) is considered **black**
4. **Red nodes' children** must be **black** (no Red-Red adjacency)
5. All paths from any node to leaves have the **same number of black nodes**

ðŸ’¡ **Important Concept: NIL Nodes**
When a node has no left or right child, that position is considered an **invisible black NIL node**.
This matters because NIL nodes count when calculating "black height"!

**Observe the example tree on the right, then click "I Understand" to continue.**

colors.title: The Meaning of Colors
colors.desc:
Now you know Red-Black Trees have two colors. But **why do we need colors**?

**What colors do:**
- **Black** nodes: Called "stable" nodes, like the tree's skeleton
- **Red** nodes: Called "flexible" nodes, can be "borrowed" during adjustments

**The most important rule: No Red-Red adjacency!**
- If a red node's parent is also red, it's a violation
- This rule ensures the tree doesn't grow too lopsided

**Observe the example tree:**
- Can you find any red node whose parent is also red?
- If not, the tree is valid!

In later lessons, you'll learn how to fix "Red-Red" violations.

black_height.title: Black Height
black_height.desc:
This is one of the most fundamental concepts in Red-Black Trees!

**What is "Black Height"?**
When you walk from a node down to any leaf, count the **black** nodes you pass. That count is the black height.

ðŸ’¡ **Important: Leaf children (NULL) count as black!**
Every leaf node (with no children) has left and right child positions that are invisible but considered **black NIL nodes**.
When calculating black height, these invisible NIL nodes count too!

**Key rule: All paths must have the same black height!**
- Starting from the root, whether you go left or right
- Reaching any leaf, the number of black nodes passed is always the same (including the final NIL)

ðŸ’¡ **Why does this matter?**
This rule ensures the tree isn't deep on one side and shallow on the other, guaranteeing search efficiency!

**Practice:**
Look at the tree on the right, try counting:
1. From root, taking the leftmost path - how many black nodes?
2. From root, taking the rightmost path - how many black nodes?
3. The two numbers should be equal!

rotations.title: Rotation Operations
rotations.desc:
**Rotation** is the key technique for fixing Red-Black Tree violations!

ðŸ’¡ **What is rotation?**
"Rotating" the tree changes parent-child relationships without changing their size order.

**Two types of rotation:**
- **Left Rotate**: Rotate a node to the left
- **Right Rotate**: Rotate a node to the right

**How to operate:**
In this playground, you can **drag nodes** to perform rotations:
- Drag a node left = Left rotation
- Drag a node right = Right rotation

**Try it now:**
1. Find a node in the tree
2. Drag it left or right with your mouse
3. Observe how the tree structure changes

This skill will be used frequently in later lessons!

foundation_quiz.title: Foundation Quiz
foundation_quiz.desc:
Congratulations on completing the basics! Let's test your understanding.

Observe the example tree on the right and answer this question:

ðŸ’¡ **Remember:** NULL children of leaf nodes count as black!
foundation_quiz.question: What is the "Black Height" of this tree? (From root to any leaf, how many black nodes? Remember to include the final NIL)

insert_case0.title: Simple Insert (No Violation)
insert_case0.desc:
Now let's learn insert operations!

**Basic insert rule:**
New nodes are **always inserted as red**. Why?
- Inserting black immediately breaks the "equal black height" rule
- Inserting red is safer, at worst violates "no Red-Red"

**The simplest case:**
If the new node's parent is **black**, no problem! No fix needed.

**Your task:**
1. Enter **3** in the input box below and click "Insert"
2. Watch the **Algorithm Log** on the right to see how the system handles it

ðŸ’¡ The system will auto-switch to "Auto" mode so you can observe the entire process.

insert_case1_1.title: Insert Case 1-1: Uncle is Red (Recolor)
insert_case1_1.desc:
Let's look at the case that needs **recoloring** only!

**Wiki Reference: Insert Case 1**

**Situation:**
- Parent is Red, Uncle is Red
- No rotation needed yet, just color changes

**Fix method:**
1. Make parent **black**
2. Make uncle **black**
3. Make grandparent **red**

This "pushes" the red upward. In this level, the Grandparent becomes Red but its parent is Black, so no new violation occurs.

**Your task:**
1. Insert **5**
2. Recolor Parent and Uncle to Black
3. Recolor Grandparent to Red

insert_case1_2.title: Insert Case 1-2: Uncle is Red (Root Fix)
insert_case1_2.desc:
What if the Red color travels to the Root?

**Wiki Reference: Insert Case 1**

**Situation:**
- Same as before: Parent Red, Uncle Red
- BUT: Grandparent is the **Root**

**Fix method:**
1. First apply standard fix: Parent Black, Uncle Black, Grandparent Red
2. **Critical Rule:** Root must always be **BLACK**!
3. So, finally turn the Root back to **Black**

This is how the Red-Black tree increases its Black Height.

**Your task:**
1. Insert **1**
2. Fix the Red-Red violation
3. Observe the Root becoming Red, then fix it!

insert_case2_1.title: Insert Case 2-1: Left-Left Line
insert_case2_1.desc:
When uncle is black and forms a **line** (not triangle):

**Wiki Reference: Insert Case 2 (Line)**

**This case's shape: Line**
- New node is parent's **left** child
- Parent is grandparent's **left** child
- Forms a "left-left" line

**Fix method:**
1. Make parent **black**
2. Make grandparent **red**
3. **Right-rotate** the **grandparent**

ðŸ’¡ Remember: Recolor first, then rotate!

**Your task:**
1. Insert **5**
2. Observe the Line: 15(GP) -> 10(P) -> 5(New)
3. Follow hints: Recolor â†’ Rotate

insert_case2_2.title: Insert Case 2-2: Right-Right Line
insert_case2_2.desc:
This is the mirror version of Case 2-1!

**Wiki Reference: Insert Case 2 (Line)**

**This case's shape: Line**
- New node is parent's **right** child
- Parent is grandparent's **right** child
- Forms a "right-right" line

**Fix method:**
1. Make parent **black**
2. Make grandparent **red**
3. **Left-rotate** the **grandparent**

**Your task:**
1. Insert **25**
2. Observe the Line: 15(GP) -> 20(P) -> 25(New)
3. Execute the fix steps

insert_case3_1.title: Insert Case 3-1: Left-Right Triangle
insert_case3_1.desc:
When uncle is **black (or doesn't exist)**, we need rotation!

**Wiki Reference: Insert Case 3 (Triangle)**

**This case's shape: Triangle (zigzag)**
- New node is parent's **right** child
- Parent is grandparent's **left** child
- Forms a "left-right" zigzag

**Fix method (two steps):**
1. First **left-rotate** the **parent** (turning triangle into a line)
2. Then handle the resulting line case (detailed in next lesson)

**Your task:**
1. Insert **7**
2. Observe the Triangle: 10(GP) -> 5(L) -> 7(R)
3. Use "Show Hint" and follow the steps to fix

insert_case3_2.title: Insert Case 3-2: Right-Left Triangle
insert_case3_2.desc:
This is the mirror version of Case 3-1!

**Wiki Reference: Insert Case 3 (Triangle)**

**This case's shape: Triangle (zigzag)**
- New node is parent's **left** child
- Parent is grandparent's **right** child
- Forms a "right-left" zigzag

**Fix method (two steps):**
1. First **right-rotate** the **parent** (turning triangle into a line)
2. Then handle the resulting line case

**Your task:**
1. Insert **22**
2. Observe the Triangle: 20(GP) -> 25(R) -> 22(L)
3. Follow hints to fix

insert_challenge.title: Insert Challenge
insert_challenge.desc:
Time to prove your skills! This challenge tests all three cases sequentially.

**Insert the following numbers in order:**

1. **Foundation:** 20, 10, 30
2. **Case 1 (Uncle Red):** Insert **5**
3. **Case 2 (Line):** Insert **4**
4. **Setup Next:** Insert **40**
5. **Case 3 (Triangle):** Insert **35**

Complete this sequence to build a perfect Red-Black Tree!

delete_red_leaf.title: Delete Red Leaf Node
delete_red_leaf.desc:
Now let's learn delete operations!

**Delete complexity:**
Deletion is more complex than insertion because we must consider the deleted node's color and child situation.

**Simplest case: Delete a red leaf node**
- "Leaf node": A node with no children
- Deleting a red node **doesn't affect black height**
- So just delete it directly, no fix needed!

**Your task:**
1. Find node **5** (should be a red leaf)
2. Enter **5** and click "Delete"
3. Observe: the tree is still valid after deletion!

delete_red_replacement.title: Delete Black Node (Red Replacement)
delete_red_replacement.desc:
What if we need to delete a **black** node?

**This case: Black node has a red child**
- Deleting a black node decreases black height (violation!)
- But if it has a red child, this child "replaces" it
- Just make this **red replacement node black**!

ðŸ’¡ **Why does this work?**
That position was originally black, after replacement it's still black, black height unchanged.

**Your task:**
1. Find node **5** (it's black, but has a red child 2)
2. Delete **5**
3. Click hint, make the replacement node (2) black

delete_case1.title: Delete Case 1: Sibling is Red
delete_case1.desc:
After deleting a black node, a "double-black" problem may occur.

**Wiki Reference: Delete Case 1**

ðŸ’¡ **What is double-black?**
After deleting a black node, that position "lacks one black", needs to "borrow" one from elsewhere.

**Case 1: Sibling node is red**
- "Sibling" is your parent's other child
- If sibling is red, we need to first turn it into a black case

**Fix method:**
1. Make sibling **black**
2. Make parent **red**
3. Rotate parent
4. Continue processing (may become case 2, 3, or 4)

**Your task:**
Follow hints to delete **10** and fix

delete_case2.title: Delete Case 2: All Black Family
delete_case2.desc:
When sibling and both its children are all black:

**Wiki Reference: Delete Case 2**

**Case description:**
- Sibling is **black**
- Sibling's two children (if any) are also **black**
- No red nodes to "borrow" from

**Fix method:**
Make sibling **red**

ðŸ’¡ **Effect of this:**
- Both sides "lack one black", relatively balanced
- But problem moves up to parent, may need continued processing

**Your task:**
Delete **10** and observe the fix process

delete_case3.title: Delete Case 3: Near Nephew is Red
delete_case3.desc:
When sibling is black and the nephew **closer to us** is red:

**Wiki Reference: Delete Case 3**

ðŸ’¡ **What are "near nephew" and "far nephew"?**
- "Near nephew": among sibling's children, the one closer to us
- "Far nephew": among sibling's children, the one farther from us

**Case description:**
- Sibling is **black**
- Near nephew is **red**
- Far nephew is **black** (or doesn't exist)

**Fix method:**
1. Make near nephew **black**
2. Make sibling **red**
3. Rotate sibling
4. This becomes case 4, continue processing

**Your task:**
Delete **10** and follow hints to fix

delete_case4.title: Delete Case 4: Far Nephew is Red
delete_case4.desc:
This is the **terminal case** for delete fixup!

**Wiki Reference: Delete Case 4**

**Case description:**
- Sibling is **black**
- Far nephew is **red**

**Fix method:**
1. **Set sibling's color to match parent's**
2. Make parent **black**
3. Make far nephew **black**
4. Rotate parent

âœ… **After these steps, fixup is complete!**

This is the most important case, must remember!

**Your task:**
Delete **10** and complete the fix

delete_challenge.title: Delete Challenge
delete_challenge.desc:
Congratulations on learning all delete cases!

Now for a challenge without looking at hints:

**Task:**
1. Delete **25**
2. Delete **75**
3. Judge what fix is needed yourself
4. Execute fixes to restore valid state

ðŸ’¡ Remember delete cases:
- Red leaf: delete directly
- Red replacement: replacement becomes black
- Cases 1-4: judge based on sibling and nephew colors

final_challenge.title: Final Challenge
final_challenge.desc:
You've learned all Red-Black Tree operations!

**Ultimate Challenge: Mixed Operations**

Without looking at any hints, complete these tasks:

1. Insert **5** (fix all violations)
2. Insert **25** (fix all violations)
3. Delete **10** (fix all violations)

Ensure the final tree is completely valid:
- No Red-Red adjacency
- All paths have same black height

Can you do it? ðŸ’ª

guide.helpDesc: A Red-Black tree is a self-balancing binary search tree where each node has an extra bit for color (Red or Black).

wiki.conceptDesc: A Red-Black Tree is a self-balancing binary search tree where each node has an extra bit for color (Red or Black).
wiki.nilNodesDesc:
**NIL Nodes** (External Nodes) are key to Red-Black Trees:

- Every `null` child pointer is treated as a **Black NIL Node**
- Leaf nodes actually have two black NIL children
- NIL nodes **don't consume memory**, just conceptual

**Why it matters:**
- Black Height must include NIL nodes
- Red nodes can have NIL children (since they are black)
- Deleting black nodes often involves NILs creating 'double black' issues
wiki.propertiesDesc:
1. Every node is either **red** or **black**.
2. The **root** is always **black**.
3. Every leaf (NIL/null) is **black** - missing children count as black nodes.
4. If a node is **red**, then both its children are **black** (No Red-Red).
5. All paths from any node to its descendant NIL nodes contain the **same number of black nodes** (black-height).
wiki.blackHeightDesc:
**Black Height** is the number of black nodes from a node to its descendant leaves (excluding the node itself).

**Why it matters:**
- All paths must have the same black height (Property 5).
- Insert/Delete operations aim to preserve this (or fix via rotation/recolor).
- Deleting a black node reduces path black height, causing violations.
wiki.insertionDesc:
Always insert new nodes as **RED**. Then fix any violations:

**Case 1: Uncle is RED**
- **Action**: Recolor Parent/Uncle to Black, Grandparent to Red.
- **Why**: Pushes redness up without affecting black height.

**Case 2: Uncle is BLACK (Line)**
- **Action**: Recolor (Parentâ†’Black, GPâ†’Red), then Rotate Grandparent.
- **Why**: Balances the height locally.

**Case 3: Uncle is BLACK (Triangle)**
- **Action**: Rotate Parent to form Line (Case 2), then fix Case 2.
wiki.deletionDesc:
Deletion is more complex than insertion:

1. **Find** the node and remove it (standard BST delete)
2. If deleted node was **RED**: No fixup needed
3. If deleted node was **BLACK**: Creates a 'double-black' situation

**Delete Fixup Cases:**
- **Case 1**: Sibling is RED â†’ Recolor + Rotate parent
- **Case 2**: Sibling BLACK, both nephews BLACK â†’ Recolor sibling
- **Case 3**: Sibling BLACK, near nephew RED â†’ Rotate sibling
- **Case 4**: Sibling BLACK, far nephew RED â†’ **Recolor Sib to Parent** + Rotate parent

In manual mode, you must perform these fixes step-by-step.
wiki.complexityDesc:
| Operation | Avg | Worst |
|-----------|-----|-------|
| Search | O(log n) | O(log n) |
| Insert | O(log n) | O(log n) |
| Delete | O(log n) | O(log n) |

**Space**: O(n)

**Advantages over AVL**:
- Fewer rotations during updates
- Simpler implementation
- Better for write-heavy workloads
